thread.title: H.S. girls tennis: Indian Hills advances in states - Girls Tennis
thread.title_full: H.S. girls tennis: Indian Hills advances in states - Girls Tennis - NorthJersey.com

author: BOB SHWALB
title: H.S. girls tennis: Indian Hills advances in states - Girls Tennis
text:
FRANKLIN LAKES – The fate of Indian Hills’ tennis team rested in the hands of doubles partners Caroline Smith and Jade Pace.
And yet, it wasn’t until their match was finished that the two had any clue.
"We had no idea what was going on with the match," Pace said. "We only knew our third singles player won because we took over on that court.
"We’d rather not know … there’s less pressure," Smith added. "I had a feeling our team won because everyone was playing really well."
On Thursday, Smith and Pace were thrilled to discover their victory gave the fourth-seeded Braves a 3-2 win over No. 13 Bergenfield in the opening round of the North 1, Group 3 state tournament.
Indian Hills will play fifth-seeded NV/Old Tappan on Tuesday in the quarterfinals.
"We’re just glad we won," Smith said. "Now we’re going to try our best to win the whole thing.
"It’s go hard or go home."
Indian Hills went home winners by the slimmest of margins.
The Braves’ first point came in third singles as recently crowned Bergen County tournament large schools champion Ariella Shlugleyt took a 6-0, 6-0 decision from Bergenfield’s Laura Armada.
On the doubles courts, the Braves’ first pair of senior Taylor Stanley and junior Jess Schlam shut out Bergenfield’s Kimberly Castor and Kareena Diamante. Their second doubles team of seniors Smith and Pace bested Arianne Guce and Angelika Milaor, 6-3, 6-0.
Bergenfield dominated at the top of the order as singles aces Jeri Ann Ramilo and Aishwarya Gandotra recorded straight-sets wins over Indian Hills’ Brianna Chase and Mansi Bhargava.
"What I admire about our team this year is we have a team," Braves coach Keith Andrews said. "Whether we win because of our singles or our doubles, all the girls work together and respect each other. That’s the most important thing."
Smith and Pace explained their own effectiveness was the result of "great chemistry."
"We never get mad at each other, and we always help each other out," Smith said. "If one of us gets frustrated, the other will help them get going again."
"We also cover each other’s strengths and weaknesses," Pace said. "I’m good at the net. And Caroline is good at the baseline, so it’s a good balance."
Stanley and Schlam said their prowess as a pair is the result of an unspoken understanding – or "telepathy" – they share on the court.
"Both of us know where the other one is going to be and what they’re going to be doing," Stanley said. "We play really well together and have a lot of fun. Other than that, I don’t know how to explain it."
